title: New Jersey Sues Over Lehman Losses
title_page: New Jersey Sues Over Lehman Losses - The New York Times
maintext:
The State of New Jersey sued former executives and directors of Lehman Brothers on Tuesday, contending that fraud and misrepresentation had caused the state’s public pension fund to lose $118 million.
The suit, filed in State Superior Court in Trenton, contends that a “thirst for profit” and “simple greed” by the Lehman executives, including the former chief executive Richard S. Fuld Jr., caused the firm to misstate its financial position when the state bought $182 million of Lehman shares in April and June 2008.
The purchases were made when Lehman was having trouble raising capital and attracting investors in the months leading up to its September bankruptcy filing.
This is the second lawsuit from a governmental entity that names former Lehman executives as defendants. Because direct claims against the firm are stayed by bankruptcy proceedings, former Lehman executives have been named instead. Last November, San Mateo County, Calif., accused Mr. Fuld and other Lehman executives of making false statements that had led to a $150 million loss in the county’s investment pool.
